1. Pivotal trial of early monoclonal antibodies reduces death & hospitalization (big, this is‚Ä¶

MA residents >75 year of age will be able to make an appointment get COVID-19 vaccine starting Feb 1 per @MassDPH.  You may be able sign up earliest tomorrow for the Feb slots. A map and downloadable list of vaccination sites can be accessed here: https://t.co/p91RWzjHGs
@johnfay45702521 It‚Äôs not good news but potentially exciting findings that could help us explain long covid down the road.

There are a lot of steps to connecting the dots between harmful immune response attacking body and long covid. Hence, this is not definitive. It's just something to study more. This phenomenon has been noted after other viral infections as well but importance remains unclear.

There seem to be a lot of reports of people having persistent symptoms, long covid, after infection. Our study hints that we should look to see if these patients developed these types of harmful antibodies during acute illness which may still be plaguing them.

Here's the bottom line on general terms: A small group of COVID-19 survivors who were initially outpatient seemed to develop antibodies against targets in their own bodies after their initial infection which seemed to last in some cases up to 7 months out. https://t.co/sFZrnt6N3N

@roby_bhatt Yes excellent idea. I wouldn't be surprised. That's why there needs to be more prospective defining of long covid and linkage between AABs and that phenotype if one wants to strengthen this story.
This highlights importance of further investigation of autoimmunity during SARS-CoV-2 infection and its role in the onset and persistence of post-acute sequelae of COVID-19.

These are small numbers. This is a signal and not definitive: Our findings support existing studies suggesting induction of immune responses to self-epitopes during acute, severe COVID-19 with evidence of general B cell hyperactivation.

Compared to pre-pandemic non- SLE controls, subjects with acute COVID-19 had higher total IgG concentration (p-value=0.006) but convalescent subjects did not (p-value=0.08); no differences in total IgA levels were found between groups.
Within the convalescent subject group, AABs were detected in 5/5 with reported persistent symptoms, potential "long covid" phenotype" and 2/4 of those without continued symptoms (p = 0.17).

Partial Least Squares Determinant Analysis (PLSDA) helped us identify anti-Beta 2-Glycoprotein, anti-Proteinase 3-ANCA, anti-Mi-2 & anti-PM/Scl-100 defined convalescent group; anti-Proteinase 3- ANCA, anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1, anti-RNP/SM defined acute COVID-19 subjects

In multivariate analysis, AAB detection was higher SLE BUT also convalescent SARSCoV2 subjects [OR 17.4, 95% CI, 2.0 ‚Äì 287.4, p = 0.02] and high but not significant in those w acute COVID- 19 compared with non-SLE pre-pandemic controls,  [OR 1.8,95% CI, 0.6 ‚Äì 8.1, p = 0.23]

We compared 18 autoimmune antibodies (AABs) across acute COVID-19 hospitalized patients, convalescent SARS-CoV-2 w mild outpatient illness, and prepandemic general population + SLE samples. We also measured total IgG and IgG across all groups except SLE.

So far, pathophysiology of acute COVID-19 appears to be combo direct viral invasion, coagulopathy & an overactive hyperinflammatory immune response. New data is hinting autoimmunity may be a critical component of the maladaptive immune reaction. https://t.co/6hFrFLqKXm

Excited to present early data from our #COVID19 survivor work. Small sample size, preprint, caveats outlined. 

We detected autoimmune antibodies in patients who survived SARS-CoV-2 infection (up to 7M out) at statistically higher rates than in unexposed üßµhttps://t.co/VBNr7jR4zn

In resource rich settings, we often think mortality is determined by the nature of the infection, the host human and medical vulnerabilities, and whether or not we have effective treatments. But we forget that, during pandemics, the impact on health systems also determines IFR.
